document.bingtitle: Bye bye supersizing, hello downsizing: Cut calories by opting for ...
document.webtitle: Bye bye supersizing, hello downsizing: Cut calories by opting for smaller portions - but would you pay the same for less food? | Mail Online
document.description: ... opting for smaller portions - but would you pay ... offering customers the option to downsize on fast food restaurant ... in the UK are when it comes to wrapping up my food ...
document.body:
Home News U.S. Sport TV&Showbiz; Femail Health Science Money RightMinds Coffee Break Travel Columnists
Femail Home Jubilee Food Pictures Femail Boards Fashion Store Beauty MyDish Recipe Finder Baby Blog Deals
My Profile Logout Login Find a Job M&S;Wine Our Papers Feedback Thursday, Jul 12 2012 9PM 9°C 12AM 10°C 5-Day Forecast Bye bye supersizing, hello downsizing: Cut calories by opting for smaller portions - but would you pay the same for less food?
By Daisy Dumas UPDATED: 21:05 GMT, 9 February 2012
Comments ( 30 ) Share
Supersizing has, in recent years, been linked to obese America. It perhaps stands to reason, then, that downsizing - exercising restraint when it comes to portion control - could help combat the obesity epidemic.
Encouraging new findings suggest that Americans could whittle down obesity levels by simply offering customers the option to downsize on fast food restaurant menus.
Not only are consumers open to trying smaller portions, found the study, published by Health Affairs yesterday, but they cut calories by doing so - and left the equivalent amount of food behind to that of a normal-sized portion.
Simple solution: A third of customers chose to downsize to a smaller side dish, eating 200 fewer calories by doing so, according to a new study
The findings may offer an alternative to dieting that is based upon calories of different food types, focusing instead on simply eating less.
Led by behavioural psychologist, Janet Schwartz, Tulane University researchers watched a group of diners at a fast food Chinese restaurant in Durham, North Carolina, reports ABC's Good Morning America .
More...
Fat? No, Adele is a normal human being... which is more than you can say for Karl Lagerfeld! Half of single women carry a pair of sexy knickers in their handbag…just in case
Unaware they were being observed, customers were given the choice to downsize to a smaller portion of a side dish.
The scientists found that a third of the customers opted for the smaller portion and by doing so, immediately omitted 200 calories from their meals.
Dr Schwartz told the programme's site that 'suggesting a smaller portion allows people to satisfy a desire for a food and does not force them to sacrifice what they want to eat'.
Fries with that? Morgan Spurlock famously popularised the term 'supersizing'
She explained that the a major stumbling block for dieters is that calories counts on foods have not helped to lower consumption levels.
And, as 'substituting a salad for a Big Mac is not an appealing choice', it makes sense to simply encourage people to eat smaller portions of what they do like.
By instilling portion control into meal times, calories are restricted and the 'cultural' urge to finish the plate is still satisfied. 'Culturally, Americans do not respond to the cue of "feeling full." The cue to stop eating is only when the plate is empty', Dr Schwartz told GMA.
Teaching people that they can reduce calories without being wholly denied of certain foods will, the scientists hope, help them to look at meals, including drink options, differently.
While the restaurant had at first been tentative to offer the choice, fearing customers may feel offended and that value is a customer's key concern, managers soon found that the restaurant was saving money, too.
Morgan Spurlock famously coined the term 'supersizing' in his documentary Supersize Me, which held a spotlight to the worrying culture of being offered to upgrade to a larger portion size for a small sum at major fast food chains such as McDonald's.
At the North Carolina eatery, not only did a 25 cent price reduction for the downsized option prove irrelevant to customer's decisions, but the study confirmed the findings of an earlier report that suggested customers would accept less food if offered, but would not ask for a smaller portion, unprompted.

Comments ( 30 )
Here's what other readers have said. Why not debate this issue live on our message boards.
The comments below have not been moderated.
Newest Oldest Best rated Worst rated View all wow.I was in the UK for 4 months...the waiters must have thought I was a real slob,....I asked to take home my un eaten food every day...I visited the same restaurants...like the same 5 anyway...I bet they had a good laugh at me.......
- Helena, Montana..., 11/2/2012 03:24 Click to rate Rating 2 Report abuse
Ellie makes a good point - but while asking for the uneaten portion of your restaurant meal'to go'is commonplace in the States it is very unusual here in the UK and I think most of us are too embarassed to ask the waiter. Maybe if more of us got into the habit of requesting our leftovers to take home in a box it would become the norm in restauraants and we wouldn't be tempted to finish a meal just because we have paid for it though we aren't really hungry.
- Daddy Longlegs, Planet Earth, 10/2/2012 23:55 Click to rate Rating 4 Report abuse
I take any food I don't eat away with me. I have no compunction about asking, either in the US or in the UK, where it is less common. I've been pleasantly surprised by how willing various restaurants and pubs in the UK are when it comes to wrapping up my food for me. I hate wasting food. I've paid for it, it's mine to take away!
- Ellie, Here, 10/2/2012 19:19 Click to rate Rating 9 Report abuse
What's it called -'The Bleedin'Obvious Diet'?
- Josie, Leeds, UK, 10/2/2012 19:00 Click to rate Rating 7 Report abuse
A lot of modern restaurants now offer smaller plates and sharing plates. I think the whole culture of huge portions started when restaurants began using those big pasta style plates with the deep rim round the age - the bowl part of the plate is wide and has a bit of depth to it. It doesn't help when you add wine glasses that take a third of a bottle either. I can remember going out to wine bars in London in the 80s when you'd get 5 - 6 glasses from a bottle because that was the size of the glasses you were given. You were only given larger glasses for red.
- Linda, Fife, 10/2/2012 17:34 Click to rate Rating 8 Report abuse
I ask to have the meal cut in half and put in a box right when I get it, so I don't have good food staring at me when I'm full :-) Now I have breakfast too.
- Alexis, San Diego, CA, 10/2/2012 17:28 Click to rate Rating 10 Report abuse
I try to cut out carbs but then I eat much more meat- but then you should cut down on meat, as it can cause bowel cancer and fibre is needed for your stomach. I love milk but told it adds lots of extra calories, but supposedly women under 30 are supposed to have plenty for healthy bones in later life. Best have everything in moderation- because you can't win cutting things out completely!
- squirrel83, Sheffield, 10/2/2012 16:28 Click to rate Rating 12 Report abuse
Does Britain have to go boxes?
- camilla villiams, Town, Country, 10/2/2012 14:14 Click to rate Rating 6 Report abuse
lc, uk, 10/02/2012 09:36 The reason you think you need food like pasta and bread is because you're hooked on carbs. Human beings can survive perfectly well on meat, fish, eggs and vegetables and indeed can get to their ideal weight without feeling hungry. It'll take 3 weeks but you'll do it. Also you don't want to know what wheat does to your gut...not good. Read Wheat Belly to find out more.
- simon, Shropshire, 10/2/2012 13:22 Click to rate Rating 3 Report abuse
Large meals put me off but I just leave what I can't eat. It's about self control. Just because it's there doesn't mean you have to eat it all.
- lenny, Wales, 10/2/2012 12:23 Click to rate Rating 17 Report abuse
The views expressed in the contents above are those of our users and do not necessarily reflect the views of MailOnline.
